The camera can lie. Arthur Conan Doyle, creator of the Sherlock Holmes stories, believed himself to be a rational man and a scientist. In 1920, he saw photographs of fairies taken in a garden setting and thought that these tiny creatures really existed. He published the photographs alongside an article he wrote, acknowledging fairies as supernatural wonders. It was not until 1939 that the two ladies who took the photos admitted these were fake. They simply cut out pictures of fairies from a book and arranged them among flowers. The results are undeniably beautiful. But the simplicity of the trick undermines a basic principle of photography, that the camera cannot lie. From the moment cameras began capturing reality, that reality was being altered.

Blacksmiths have been skilled craftsmen for many years. They have been making weapons, armour and farming tools since the beginning of time. In the past, blacksmiths were highly respected and were often compared to doctors and astrologers. Today, blacksmiths are not as widely used, but they are still admired for their artistry.
There has been a recent revival in blacksmithing thanks to greater interest in decorative architecture and a less conservative approach to interior design. Artists now have a new material that allows them to express themselves more freely. The metal is soft when it is hot, but it becomes rigid and immovable when it cools down.
Many blacksmiths are fascinated by the unique properties of iron. They love the fact that it is cold and hard, and the way it feels as though it is there forever. No other base metal can give man as much visual pleasure, or a greater feeling of security.

The day I gave up smoking, I was pleased that everyone would be happy. But one of my colleagues was very angry. "What do you mean?" she raged. "If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I guess my inability to explain how I had been a smoker for many years and how I was not anymore was a little annoying. The stop-smoking session was an interesting mixture of group therapy and hypnotherapy and it took place exactly two months and three weeks ago. I had not intended to stop and I did not even particularly want to. But I did stop. The physical craving and the pangs of desire for nicotine faded after a few days. I am increasingly coming to the view that smoking had a great deal to do with displacing boredom. Yes, I do miss my cigarettes, but not too much.

Dorothy Hodgkin was a British woman scientist who won the Nobel prize in chemistry in 1964 for her work on penicillin and vitamin B12. She was also a mother of three and wife to a historian.
Hodgkin's most important successes were solving the structure of penicillin and vitamin B12. She pushed the technique into realms of complexity others deemed unreachable at the time.
There is much to learn from Hodgkin's life. She was a successful scientist and a loving mother. Her story is an inspiration to all.

Margaret Wilkins is said to have a 'sixth sense' that allows her to locate water. She can hold a forked hazel rod above the ground and detect water. She is increasingly in demand by farmers whose wells have dried up. Together with her husband, Margaret Wilkins runs a well-drilling business.
Margaret tries to locate water between 50 and 70 meters down. She uses a map of the area and a pendulum to find likely areas. Once she has found the likely areas, she walks over the fields with a hazel stick. If there is water below, the stick rises up. If there is no water, the stick does not rise up.
Margaret Wilkins is not in isolation. Anthropologists and writers have long been fascinated by this inexplicable intuition. If she did not have this 'sixth sense', how else could the family live off their well-drilling business year after year?

We changed lives for a day! Have you ever dreamed about swapping lives with someone else for a day? Perhaps you think it would be more fun to do something quite different for a change. We fixed it for four people - read how it went.
A. Amanda's story I couldn't believe how dark and noisy it was at the restaurant. It was all a far cry from my home town and, to he honest, I wasn't sure I'd survive! Being a mother is definitely a busy job - but this was something else! I had just fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks at shoulder height with one hand. The other waitresses made it look so simple, but just as I was getting the hang of it, the drinks started to slide off the tray and crashed on to the floor, splattering cocktails everywhere. I was so embarrassed, but all the other waitresses laughed.
B. Cindy's story I was feeling quite apprehensive about being a 'mum' for the day, but I was looking forward to it, too. As Amanda left to make her way to the restaurant, I had to get the two girls dressed and fed. But it was when I brought Sophie home from school that the real trouble started. They turned the settee into a trampoline and played a game which involved screaming as loudly as they possibly could. I decided to take the laid-back approach, imagining they'd soon get worn out. Wrong again. I thought I had a fair amount of stamina, but they beat me, hands down!
C. Rosemary's story On the farm, I have to get up early and sleep late. But I dithered for ages about how to look. There's so much to do before classes start again. I attended a staff meeting about reports and couldn't avoid getting roped in to help with athletics trials. Finally we moved on to the school hall for Physical Education. I was drained by now, but the children seemed to have inexhaustible energy.
D. Hilary's story I arrived at the farm early, but I discovered that Rosemary had been up for hours. The process of milking the cows took an exhausting two-and-a-half hours. And Rosemary does this twice a day, starting at 6 am, seven days a week, 365 days a year! I found it quite a lonely day.

A trumpet is not just for Christmas. It is strange that many musicians, even leading ones, come from homes without music. Hakan Hardenberger is a musician who has established himself as unique among the world's trumpet-players today. He was born in southern Sweden and has a unique talent for playing the trumpet. His records are continually opening up new repertory, not just concertos by long-neglected composers, but new works too.
Hardenberger was born near Malmo and owes his career to the accident of a Christmas present when he was only eight. His father had the idea of giving his only son a trumpet. The success of the gift was instant. The boy never stopped playing. He had a natural talent for playing the trumpet and was taught by a teacher who was also passionate about the instrument.
Hardenberger has a unique gift of communicating through his music. He is able to move people with his playing. He has won many competitions and has performed in many concert halls around the world.

New In Paperback A is a novel set in the fictional republic of Efica. The book is notable for its humour, and for the author's unique vision. It also includes a story about a teenage boy who viciously attacked a young man. After the court case, both boys refuse to talk about what happened. The book follows the fortunes of one of the most isolated of the Scottish Orkney islands and its inhabitants over a long and uneventful rural history. The author is skilled at exposing the haunting sadness that hovers beneath the seeming ordinariness of life.

Career Power Get the leading edge - motivate yourself to take full control at work.
A good leader is one who inspires, motivates, and encourages others. Leadership is not about height or intelligence. It's about making things happen through people who are as enthusiastic and interested as you are. To be a good leader, you should be able to speak out clearly and confidently. You should also be able to motivate others and inspire them to believe in themselves.
Becoming a leader is recognizing your latent talents and developing them. It's also about setting goals and achieving them. If you want to be a successful leader, you need to be willing to take risks and learn from your mistakes. You also need to be able to communicate effectively and delegate tasks.
Whether you're the boss or a middle manager, you can benefit from improving your leadership skills. There are definite lessons to be learned. Find out where your passions and convictions lie. Start thinking of yourself as a leader. Set goals and achieve them. Be visible and accessible to those who are important. But bear in mind, you don't have to lead all the time.

Films on video are a popular way to enjoy movies. There are many different types of films available on video, including action, comedy, drama, and horror. Some of the most popular films on video include A Abyss Long Before Titanic, The Thin Red Line, On Guard, Character, and The Good, the Bad and the Ugly.
These films offer a variety of entertainment value for viewers of all ages. They are all well-made and enjoyable to watch. However, they are not all perfect. Some of the films have weak dialogue or characterization. Despite these flaws, the films are still enjoyable to watch.

Steve Martin's book, "Compelling Evidence," is a compelling read. The narrator, a lawyer, finds himself defending his boss's wife when she is tried for her husband's murder. The trial scenes are riveting, with the outcome in doubt right up to the verdict. The book is about 50 pages overweight, but it is still great stuff.
BOOK B, "Curtains for the Cardinal," is a historical novel set in the Italian Renaissance. The plot is convoluted and the book is about 50 pages overweight, but it is still great stuff.
BOOK C, "File Under: Deceased," introduces a new detective, Leah Hunter, who is a tax inspector. The book is about 50 pages overweight, but it is still great stuff.
BOOK D, "Double Deuce," is a detective novel by Robert B. Parker. The book is about 50 pages overweight, but it is still great stuff.
BOOK E, "False Prophet," is a mystery novel by Faye Kellermann. The book is about 50 pages overweight, but it is still great stuff.

I'm 34 years old and I'm nervous about backpacking. I've done it before, but I've been busy with my job and relationship. I decided to quit my job and rent out my flat to go travelling in South East Asia for a year.
There are a lot of reasons why people are travelling in their thirties. Some people are unhappy with their jobs, some are going through a breakup, and some just want to experience new things. I'm not sure if I'm running away or running towards something, but I'm excited about the next 12 months.
I'm also aware that there are a lot of challenges associated with backpacking. I have to make arrangements for my flat, organise my travel, and decide where to go. I'm also concerned about being out of place and feeling lonely. But I'm determined to do it. I'm going to take the opportunity to reassess my life and see what I want.

I was feeling out of touch with the changes brought about by technology. I had taken a long break from journalism and I needed to resurrect my career. I was stuck in the 1980s with my carbon typewriter. It seemed like only a madman would let me loose on a computer in his newsroom. I was the family technophobe. I had to act quickly to find a way to work from home. I won a computer package and set up a mini-office in my kitchen. I have become an organised worker and I can research stories, ask for further information, and discuss the pros and cons of working from home with people from all over the world. However, there are also some challenges associated with working from home, such as isolation, distractions, and power struggles. But I am confident that I can continue to work from home and achieve my goals.

The Tartan Museum is a modern museum in Scotland's capital, Edinburgh. It has a lot of interesting exhibits and a beautiful building. The museum is designed to be a pleasurable and visual experience for everyone, regardless of their prior knowledge.
The museum has a lot of different galleries and spaces. There are tall display cases and arrow-slit windows. There is also a Discovery Centre where children can learn about the museum's exhibits.
The museum has a temporary exhibition called the Twentieth Century gallery. It has a lot of objects that have been chosen by Scottish people and other personalities. The Prime Minister's suggestion was an electric guitar. Others went for televisions, thermos flasks and favourite toys.
Overall, the Tartan Museum is a beautiful and interesting museum. It is a must-see for anyone visiting Edinburgh.

The end of print may take some time. It's a pleasant word and a calming concept. Change may frighten some and challenge others, but it also means going surely and sweetly from somewhere present to somewhere future.
The sales of print newspapers are plummeting while visits to their websites keep on soaring. The latest print circulation figures show that many newspapers are down between 8% and 10% year-on-year. However, the latest survey of trends by the World Association of Newspapers shows that global circulation rose 1.1% last year. Sales in the West dropped back but Asia more than made up the difference.
The decline in newspaper sales is a complex issue. There are many factors that contribute to it, including timing, demography, geography, and the rise of e-readers. However, the evidence suggests that print is still a valuable tool for newspapers. It is also a crucial tool in selling internet subscriptions.
Of course, the decline in newspaper sales is a challenge for newspaper companies. However, there are a number of things that newspapers can do to adapt to the changing landscape. One thing that newspapers can do is to offer joint packages that include print and digital access. Another thing that newspapers can do is to focus on providing high-quality content.

People are the most interesting subjects to photograph. A photograph with someone in it is usually more compelling than the same shot without the human interest. People are also the most difficult subjects to photograph well. To take a good picture of people, you need to be aware of actions, gestures and expressions. And often the presence of the camera itself can have a disastrous effect on these.
To photograph people well, you need to consider the following:
- Group people at different angles and distances.
- Help your subject relax and find a comfortable position.
- Make sure the subject is not overwhelmed by the background.
- Ask your subject to look into the lens.
- Use a background that is relevant to the subject.
- Show the interaction between people.
- Take pictures of people in their natural environment.
- Balance the subjects and the place they were visiting.
- Decide whether you want to pose or not pose your subject.

Sarah Janson is an artist who creates illusions of reality through her paintings. She is not interested in being known as the artist who created the work, but rather the artist who made it possible. Janson has been painting for sixteen years and has a string of major corporate and private commissions behind her. Much of her work is inspired by architecture or made for architectural settings.
Janson's paintings are designed to deceive the eye by creating the illusion of reality. They are often inspired by architecture or made for architectural settings. There is always a danger with trompe-l'oeil, though, that once you get the joke, your attention is lost.
Janson is generous in praise of her clients and is always willing to listen to their ideas. She is also very grateful for the clients who have let her loose on their walls.

In the modern workplace, emotional intelligence (EQ) is becoming increasingly important. It is the ability to understand and manage your own emotions and the emotions of others. EQ includes basic elements such as self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy, and adeptness in social relationships.
There are many benefits to having high EQ. For example, it can help you to be more successful in your job, improve your relationships with colleagues, and make you more effective at managing your time and emotions.
In order to develop your EQ, you can practice self-reflection, mindfulness, and social skills training. You can also learn from your experiences and from the experiences of others.
By developing your EQ, you can improve your overall quality of life and become more successful in all areas of your life.

Should the media earn money from content they don't own? Although it is easier to capture newsworthy events with digital cameras and camera phones, social media has revolutionised citizen photography. With news regularly breaking on social networks, some journalists are now turning to them as sources of images as fast-moving events occur. Unfortunately, some reporters have published user-generated content (UGC) without permission. Despite official guidance that images posted on social media can be used without permission if there are exceptional circumstances or strong public interest, there is ongoing debate about whether this is ethical. With research indicating that a significant number of people would film or photograph a news event, it is clear that UGC has a major role to play in the future of the media. However, if the media is to maintain its relationship with the public, steps must be taken to ensure that people are properly rewarded for their work and that permission is always sought.

Ancient Chinese medicine, also known as acupuncture, is a traditional Chinese system of medicine that has been used for centuries. It is used to treat many different conditions, but acupuncture's role in treating pain has received the most attention.
Acupuncture involves inserting fine needles into the skin at specific points on the body. These points are related to meridians, which are lines of energy that flow through the body. When the flow of energy is disrupted, the body becomes unbalanced and can experience pain.
Acupuncture can be effective for treating a variety of pain conditions, including back pain, arthritis, headaches, and migraines. It is also sometimes used to treat other conditions, such as menstrual pain and facial nerve pain.
If you are considering acupuncture for pain relief, it is important to find a qualified acupuncturist. You should also discuss your condition with your doctor to see if acupuncture is right for you.

P. D. James, a best-selling crime writer, is known for her intricate and brilliant imagination. She exudes an air of quiet authority, but it is soon apparent that she is actually shy. She has written 12 major detective novels that are read avidly by millions worldwide. She is a great fan of the works of close friend Ruth Rendell and enjoys reading detective stories.
James was born in Oxford and grew up mainly in Cambridge. She worked full-time in administration for the National Health Service and made good use of her organizational skills. She became 'quite accustomed' to seeing corpses while working in forensic science. But it was not fascination with death itself that inspired her. It was the shape and construction involved in the writing of a crime novel that appealed to her.
James believes that writing detective stories is a way of bringing order out of disorder. The solution of a crime confirms the sanctity of life, even if that life is unlovable. Nobody really likes violence.

The pen is mightier than the psychoanalyst. Handwriting analysis, or graphology, is accepted as a genuine science in many countries. It can be used to indicate certain illnesses, such as heart disease and cancer, and can reveal psychological states and emotional disturbances. Graphology can also be used for vocational guidance and as an adjunct to interviews.
Handwriting can reveal other psychological characteristics, such as whether a person is honest, manipulative, or reliable. It can also be used to predict would-be suicides. However, there is little hard evidence to support such claims. Some psychiatrists are highly critical of them.

Is your office working ok? Fresh air and comfortable chairs are the key to a happy, healthy workforce, according to a new survey. We went to four different offices to find out how healthy and happy they were as working environments. We spoke to an expert panel including a building health consultant, an ergonomist, and an occupational psychologist. Here are their verdicts.
Office A is a small office with a lot of natural light. The air is fresh and the chairs are comfortable. The team of seven people who work there are happy and healthy.
Office B is a comfortable office with good air quality and plenty of space. The chairs are excellent and the lighting is good. However, the office is a bit impersonal and unstimulating.
Office C is a busy office with a lot of activity. The air is not stale and the chairs are adequate. However, the office is a bit cramped and the panelling and carpet give a sombre effect.
Office D is a dusty office with a lot of problems. The air-conditioning control is very crude, the space is cluttered, and the office is very dusty. The furniture is old and uncomfortable.

Chewing gum is a popular fashion accessory in the United States, where people chew an average of 12 million sticks a day. Gum is made from a natural substance called chicle, which is obtained from the sapodilla tree. In the past, people chewed gum made from spruce resin or mastic gum. Today, most gum is made synthetically. Gum has a number of health benefits, including reducing tooth decay. It also helps to relax and ease tension. Gum manufacturers say that chewing gum for 20 minutes can increase your salivary flow.

The Ghanerao Hotel in India and the Hermitage Hotel in New Zealand are two charming hotels that offer a unique blend of tranquility and beauty. The Ghanerao Hotel is situated in a small rural village dominated by craftsmen, while the Hermitage Hotel is nestled amidst stunning natural surroundings. Both hotels provide basic facilities, but their spartan aspects add to their appeal.
The Paradis Hotel on Mauritius is another tranquil retreat. It is isolated on its own peninsula, offering a private beach and breathtaking views of the Indian Ocean. The Ladera Hotel in St. Lucia is known for its dramatic setting and colonial style. The Splendid Hotel in Istanbul is a historic gem, offering a glimpse into the past and a chance to escape the hustle and bustle of the city.
The Fairview Hotel in Kenya is a comfortable and affordable option for travellers. It is located on Nairobi Hill, offering serene gardens and a relaxed atmosphere. The Hotel Splendido in Portofinto, Italy, is steeped in history and offers a luxurious atmosphere. Its former guests include Lauren Bacall, Humphrey Bogart, and Liz Taylor.
These hotels offer a variety of amenities and services, but they all share a common thread - the ability to provide a peaceful and memorable escape.

The hotel inspector Sue Brown judges hotels for a living. One day, she was inspecting the Globe Hotel. Things were not going well from the beginning. The receptionist was reciting room rates over the phone to a potential guest, but she was not paying attention to Sue. Sue was not impressed by the hotel's rating or its service. There were a few problems with the hotel, such as a gaping panel in the wardrobe and a hole in the wall. Sue also found out that the hotel was not very clean. However, she did praise the assistant manager and the waitress for their hard work. Dinner was also good, which made Greaves happy. But there was one more problem. Another inspector will be back to make sure that everything has been put right.

Seven Up Mountaineer Doug Scott shares his experience of conquering the highest peak on each continent, the Seven Summits. My quest to climb the Seven Summits came late in life. I climbed the Seven Summits in the order I completed them.
A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)
I was talking to my feet and recalling other climbers who had lost fingers and toes from frostbite. The cold was getting into my feet and I was worried about the quality of our survival.
B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)
The air pressure in the polar regions is lower, which has an impact on the body out of all proportion to its altitude. We spent the third night on a windswept ridge; by now we were both suffering.
C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,89Sm)
We got lost in the dense jungles of the lower slopes and ran out of water. We spent the second day trying to find water and came across luminous arrows painted on trees and a trail of rubbish which brought us to a rock pool.
D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)
The original and now standard route up Aconcagua is little more than a walk. We decided to miss out on the glacier and go across the north ridges instead.
E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)
When I learnt that climbing Vinson Massif was just a matter of guiding enough people in order to finance the cost of getting there, attempting all of the Seven Summits became a reality.
F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)
We walked to the refuge at 4,200m and crossed open slopes, some of them glassy ice. By mid-afternoon we reached what we thought was the summit. But we found there was another kilometre-long ridge to the actual summit.
G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)
We reached the summit by 11 am. I was given a standing ovation on this, my seventh summit. Mission accomplished!

Style Merchants Style is a company that provides information about the latest fashion trends. Jo Foley, Ned Ingham, Sally Quail, Lily Grimson, and Peter Little are some of the designers whose work is showcased by the company.
Ned Ingham designs wedding dresses. He believes that simpler styles are more flattering than traditional, stiff dresses and frilly looks. Ingham has been drawing and designing wedding dresses since he was a schoolboy. He gained the technical skills to cut and construct clothes at fashion school.
Sally Quail is a jeweller who designs necklaces, bracelets, and rings. She started designing her own jewelry when she couldn't find an engagement ring she liked. Her pieces are sought out by many stars of stage and screen.
Lily Grimson is a handbag designer. She has had two of her creations selected for a major design exhibition. Her bags are handmade in the UK and are full of glamour.
Peter Little is a hairdresser. He has been styling hair for over 20 years. He believes that real-looking hair and a style that can be managed at home are important to his clients.
Penny Pratt is a florist. She has a small shop and provides floral ideas to a number of top restaurants. She has been successful in setting up her own London Flower School.

The Merrion Hotel is a five-star hotel that has recently opened in Dublin. It is a new hotel that has been created using four large eighteenth-century houses. The hotel has a lot of technology, including a computer system that can deal with return clients and a system that controls room temperature. The hotel also has a lot of amenities, such as a swimming pool, gym, conference rooms, bars, and restaurants.
The Merrion Hotel is likely to be successful because of its technology, its amenities, and its highly capable staff.

Artist Susan Shepherd is known for her flower paintings. She has a large garden that is full of her favourite flowers, mostly tulips and poppies. Some of the plants are unruly and seed themselves all over the garden. There is a harmony of colour, shape and structure in the flower borders that line the paved path. Much of this is due to the previous owners who were keen gardeners. Susan prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants rather than on the garden as a whole. More usually, she picks them and then takes them up to her studio. Her busiest time of year is spring and early summer, when the tulips and poppies are out. She has a come-what-may attitude to the garden, rather like an affectionate aunt who is quite happy for children to run about undisciplined.

No title. Many trees in the Brackham area were blown down in a terrible storm that March. The town itself lost two great lime trees from the former market square. The disappearance of such prominent features had altered the appearance of the town centre entirely. Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, head of the local police force, was annoyed by the change. He was sick with bronchitis and couldn't concentrate. His wife, Molly, tried to persuade him to go to the doctor, but he refused. The storm had also damaged his house, but Pelham was more concerned about the loss of the trees. When he finally went to the doctor, he was prescribed antibiotics and told to rest. The loss of the trees had made a permanent difference to the appearance of the living-room. The room seemed cruelly bright and the worn furnishings were exposed. The tall house next door was now dominating the outlook. It seemed to have a great many upstairs windows, all of them watching the Pelhams' every movement.

Living in the valley, we had been living there for sixteen months when we first realized the dangers that could exist in the surrounding hills. It was the year when the storms came early, before the calendar even hinted at winter. Until that time, we had felt safe and sheltered in our valley below the protecting hills. Soon snow began to fall. It was deep and made the streamside path slippery and dangerous. But on the neighbouring heights the snow was much deeper and stayed for longer. The wind blasted fiercely. The river threatened us most. It was flowing wildly and was becoming fuller and wilder. The snow was gradually washed away as more and more rain streamed from the clouds. The dam held and the waters began to subside. We can thus enjoy, rather than fear, the huge clouds that hang over the valley.

Film Critic Mark Adams has been writing articles about films for a newspaper called The Front Page for the last ten years. He started writing articles about films before he had a proper job. He met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who also wrote for radio and television. Tom hired Mark, but he was not primarily a journalist. He had a lot of ideas for the newspaper, but they didn't all work out. Mark chose film as his area of focus. He likes the space he has to write about films in his own way. He doesn't feel he has a responsibility to be 'right' about a movie. All he has to do is put forward an argument.

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km and then run 1Okm? Because it's fun. Teenager with a taste for endurance WANTED: Sports-mad training partner for triathlete, preferably female. Chance to work with potential Olympic champion. Should be extremely keen on distance running (regular 15km sessions), distance swimming (addiction to winter training in cold rivers useful) and distance cycling (love of 1OOkm an advantage). Ability to do all three without a rest essential. The triathlon promises to be one of the most popular Olympic sports. Recently it has drawn huge crowds fascinated (and horrified) by athletes swimming 1500m, cycling 40km, then running 1Okm without stopping. Great for those watching, maybe, but what makes the triathletes want to punish their bodies so much? And what makes an attractive 17-year-old, with excellent academic results, give up everything for the doubtful pleasures it offers?
Melanie Sears has not yet learnt those often-repeated phrases about personal satisfaction, mental challenge and higher targets that most athletes automatically use when asked similar questions. 'You swim for 1500m, then run out of the water and jump on your bike, still wet. Of course, then you freeze. When the 40km cycle ride is over, you have to run 1Okm, which is a long way when you're feeling exhausted. But it's great fun, and all worth it in the end,' she says.
Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14. 'I won the junior section - but then I was the only junior taking part. It seemed so easy that I was waving at my team-mates as I went round.' Full of confidence, she entered the National Championships, and although she had the second fastest swim and the fastest run, she came nowhere. 'I was following this man and suddenly we came to the sea. We realised then that we had gone wrong. I ended up cycling 20 kilometres too far. I cried all the way through the running.' But she did not give up and is determined that she never will. 'Sometimes I wish I could stop, because then the pain would be over, but I am afraid that if I let myself stop just once, I would be tempted to do it again.' Such doggedness draws admiration from Steve Trew, the sport's director of coaching. 'I've just been testing her fitness,' he says, 'and she worked so hard on the running machine that it finally threw her off and into a wall. She had given it everything, but whereas most people step off when they realise they can't go any further, she just kept on.'
Melanie was top junior in this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. 'I was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running, but much slower at cycling. That's why I'm working very hard at it.' She is trying to talk her long-suffering parents, who will carry the PS1,300 cost of her trip to New Zealand for this year's World Championships, into buying a PS2,000 bike ('It's a special deal, with PS1,000 off) so she can try national 25 km and 100 km races later this year. But there is another price to pay. Her punishing training sessions have made her a bit of a recluse. 'I don't have a social life,' she says. 'I'm not a party animal anyway. After two hours' hard swimming on Friday nights, I just want to go to sleep. But I phone and write to the other girls in the team.'

The Collectors
Amanda Roy writes about her passion for collecting and the reasons why people enjoy this hobby. Collecting is a world of passion, envy and enthusiasm. If you enter this world, remember one thing: you must fall in love with an object before you collect it. People have been collecting things since the beginning of time. Some people collect stones and seashells just for the beauty of their forms and colours. Others collect flowers, pottery or paintings. If you are interested in collecting, there are many things you can collect. You do not have to be rich or powerful to start a collection. You can collect items as different as tulip bulbs and china cups. As small objects become a popular collector's item, they begin to rise in price.

My line of work is to put together temporary exhibitions at the Science Museum. I have to read up about the subject of the exhibition beforehand and then talk to important people in the area so that I can establish the main themes and aims of the exhibition, and plan what objects and pictures should be displayed. I also have to make sure the public can understand the thinking behind the exhibition, which means planning interactive displays, workshops and theatre.
Janet is a teacher of London taxi drivers. She checks the accounts and sees what new maps and documents need to be produced. She also gets involved when there's a difference of opinion and tells the students to use another route because the road is closed.
Sarah is a marine conservationist. She lives by the coast and works from home. She does things like take people out to sea in a boat and set up training courses.
Chris is a map and atlas publisher. He has to make sure that the publishing programme matches market requirements and ensure that they keep stocks of the books that they publish.

No title. We always go to Ireland in June. Every year, the four of us have spent the first fortnight of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It's a large house by the sea, not far from the village of Ardbeag. The Malseeds bought the house and have added to it. They have a lot of flowers in the hall. In winter, when no one much comes to Glencorn Lodge, Mrs. Malseed sees to little details like that; her husband sees to redecoration and repairs.
In the morning, we'd walk along the sands to Ardbeag and have coffee in the hotel there. In the afternoon, we'd drive somewhere. I knew all that because over the years this kind of pattern had developed. Since first we came here, we'd all fallen hopelessly in love with every variation of its remarkable landscape.

Keeping the holiday-makers happy is a chalet girl's work. Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, is a chalet girl. She works for a company in Val d'Isere, France, cooking and cleaning for visitors who come to ski and stay in the wooden houses, known as chalets.
Sarah's day begins early. She gets up at 7 a.m. and walks to the chalet. She has breakfast and prepares breakfast for the guests. After breakfast, she clears up and makes the afternoon tea. She then goes on the slopes and skis as much as possible.
In the evening, Sarah prepares dinner and takes a shower. She doesn't sleep. Dinner is served at 8 p.m. and coffee is usually on the table by 10 p.m. After dinner, she clears away the dinner things and fills the dishwasher. Sometimes she will stay and chat with the guests, other times they are content to be left alone.
On Sundays, Sarah has a busy day. She starts cleaning early and prepares tea for the new guests. Sometimes she takes guests down to the ski shop and gets a lift back to the chalet. It is soon time for dinner duty again and perhaps a drink later.

Miss Rita Cohen, a young girl, came to Seymour's factory one day. She was small and had a lot of hair. She was interested in learning about the leather industry. She asked many questions and took notes. Seymour liked finding that she was interested in every last detail. He offered to show her how gloves were made. He told her about the tannery and the history of leather. He also offered to make her a pair of gloves.

Chris Arnot asked four people with dream jobs if they're as wonderful as they seem.
A. Raquel Graham is a personal assistant to a pop star. She loves her job and gets on well with her boss, but she can't stand flying.
B. David Brown is a golf caddy. He prefers the golf to his accounting job, but there are drawbacks.
C. Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a daily newspaper. He loves to cook and thinks that expensive restaurants are worth it for those who can afford them.
D. Dick Prince is a children's writer. He loves to write and enjoys the part of being a writer that involves getting letters from fans.

In the yard by the lake, there was an old brick building two floors high. There was a lot of sawdust around the building. One afternoon, Michael was bored and he climbed up the ladder to the roof of the old building. He said, "I dare you to jump down," and he jumped off the roof and fell on the sawdust. He lay rolling around and laughing. Some of his friends followed him up to the roof and jumped down one by one. Michael was still on the roof, watching them. He was thinking about jumping down, but he didn't. He stayed on the roof for a long time. Finally, he closed his eyes and jumped off the roof. He lay there for a long time. There were no sounds in the yard. He was ashamed and wanted to avoid everybody. He walked home feeling deeply ashamed.

If you are unhappy with your job, you can turn to a careers adviser. They will ask you to write a brief history of yourself and then conduct a number of tests known as 'psychometrics'. Based on the results of the tests and your own input, the adviser will suggest various careers and the retraining needed.
Taking the careers test was like being back in your science exams. It involves picking out mistakes in lists of names and numbers, matching up similar shapes in a set, and remembering that it wasn't about passing or failing. After the test, you will have a long chat with the adviser and they will produce a report giving their observations and recommendations.
If you are considering changing your career, you should think about the pros and cons of each option. You may need to weigh the cost of retraining against your financial commitments. If you have no idea what you want to do, you can go to a careers adviser and they can help you find the right path.

If you walk into W. Lloyd Jerome's dental surgery in the centre of Glasgow, you'll see bright modern paintings on the wall and a fashionable blue couch. Jerome says that many people are afraid to go to the dentist when they're not in pain. To counteract this, he has tried to create an environment where people are not afraid. He has introduced relaxation techniques such as virtual-reality headsets and a pleasant smell in the surgery. The surgery smells more like a perfume shop than a dentist's. Today there is the smell of orange. The quality of the treatment is of course the most important thing. For example, Jerome uses a special instrument which sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them, rather than scraping them.

**
Chocolate, which has its origins in South America, is a popular treat in many countries. It is made from cacao beans, which are found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies and South-East Asia. The cacao tree is evergreen and produces a fruit that contains seeds. These seeds are dried and become cacao beans. Cacao beans can be used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often called cocoa beans. The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and to make a drink called xocoatl. The Spanish found the drink more palatable mixed with cinnamon and sugar. Chocolate houses were set up in Europe's capital cities where people gathered to drink chocolate. Until the last century, chocolate was made from solid blocks of chocolate which had to be melted down in hot water. But in 1826, chocolate powder was invented. The age of the chocolate bar as we know it began in 1847. Today, chocolate intake in Britain has stabilised at about four bars each week.

Peter Cooke is a shell artist who is known for his unique and delicate creations. He has been making beautiful objects out of shells for the past ten years. Cooke's work is characterized by its attention to detail, color gradations, and symmetry. He uses a variety of materials, including cardboard, glue, and washing-up liquid. To create his art, Cooke travels to different beaches around the world to collect shells. He insists that he only collects dead shells and defends himself against people who write him letters accusing him of stripping the world's beaches.

When 15-year-old Kira Langer is not flying to wonderful locations or appearing on magazine covers, she is usually revising for her school exams. One day, she was late for her appointment due to a problem with her transportation. If she was late, she would be rushing and in a bad mood. But when she arrived, she was smiling, relaxed and apologetic. Kira is a very friendly and tall girl. She explained that all models under the age of 16 must take an adult with them whenever they work. She also said that she has to manage her two separate lives as a busy model.

Father and son, Terence and Chris Madden, have travelled from Canada to Africa to find gold. They believe their mine on the side of a Welsh mountain could contain a lot of gold. After ten years of digging, they are convinced that they are close to a vein of gold worth millions of dollars.
The pair have dedicated their lives to the hunt for gold. They started their search after the father read about a pocket of gold worth millions of pounds buried in the Welsh town of Dolgellau. Since they first found bits of gold in the rocks, they have spent the past ten years getting permission for their work, taking samples of the earth and removing old cars and rubbish.
Now they are running short of money. They will have to convince a backer to put money into the project to lower the mine just a few more metres to where the gold lies.
The Welsh gold industry has gone into steep decline since its height in the late 1880s. However, individual gold-diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to drive a tunnel deep into the hill on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens.

Rachel Mills is a scientist who studies chemical processes happening in the sea. She teaches and does research into marine geochemistry. When she isn't teaching, she dives down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.
The dive can last for 16 hours. It takes three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to gather samples, and then three hours to get back up to the surface.
If there is a problem, you can hit a panic button and the escape vessel will be released. It's like letting go of a ping-pong ball in the bath.
Last year, Rachel dived with a Russian crew. They went to a site which was a five-day sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. Here, on the ocean floor, is a huge area of underwater volcanoes.
When Rachel isn't at sea, she is in her office at the Oceanography Centre, Southampton. Two thirds of her salary comes from teaching, which she loves.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry and tanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body and mind couldn't handle any more punishment. I was tired of foreign timetables, currencies and languages. I said, "Never again," as I stepped onto home ground. The train ticket allowed me to travel freely throughout Europe. Ordinary beds are never the same once you've slept in the corridor of a train. Carrying all your possessions on your back in a rucksack makes you have a very basic approach to travel. It encourages incredible wastefulness that can lead to burning socks and getting rid of books when finished. But this way of looking at life is entirely in the spirit of Inter-Rail. All it takes is one of those tickets in your hand. You can travel through countries at a rate of more than one a day. The excitement of travel comes from the sudden reality of somewhere that was previously just a name. It is as if the city in which you arrive never actually existed until the train pulls in at the station and you are able to see it with your own tired eyes for the first time.

**
There is nothing more disappointing than arriving at an airport overseas and finding that your baggage has been left behind. If your luggage is not with you, you may have to wear the clothes you stand up in for hours or days until the airline reunites you with your luggage. Although airlines rarely reveal how many cases they lose, it is a fact of life that sooner or later regular travellers will be parted from their luggage. The system works like this. Airlines require passengers to check in at a specific time before departure. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are designed to allow for baggage transfers. Sometimes, extra security checks and problems with air traffic can cause delays. All this can cause the baggage system to fail. If your luggage goes missing, you must contact the appropriate airline official in the baggage hall and complete a property irregularity report (PIR). This must be done before leaving the airport.

The kingfisher is a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers. It feeds on fish. The bird cuts like a laser through the scene, straight and fast. It has gone in a split second, but a trace of the image lingers. Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers at an early age. He spent a lot of time watching them. He has a lot of photographs of kingfishers.

Conducting an orchestra is challenging. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work.
A. Anne Manson is a young conductor who works with a well-established opera company in London. She has conducted several projects with Claudio Abbado.
B. Andrew Constantine won a major competition in 1991. He is finding it difficult to lose the 'competition' label.
C. Wasfi Kani started conducting seriously in her late twenties. She loves the long practice period which is part of any opera production.
D. Roger Vignoles started out as a resident musician with an opera house. He has conducted several pieces of music.
E. Wayne Marshall is a young conductor who has conducted several musical productions. He is determined and knows what he likes.

If you're thinking of taking children to a theme park in Britain, there are many to choose from. We asked five families to test the best. Fun Island, Wonderland, Adventure World, The Great Park, and Fantasy World are all popular theme parks in Britain. Each park has its own unique attractions and rides.
The children all loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel at Fun Island. At Wonderland, the Mountain Train and Little Land were popular rides. Adventure World has a Big Top Circus and Running River. The Great Park has Exotic Travels and Lightning River. Fantasy World has Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket.
There are rides for all ages at each park. For younger children, there are dodgems, the Crocodile Ride, and the Giant Wheel. For older children, there are scarier rides, such as Splash Out and the Rocket.
The parks are all well-designed and clean. The staff are friendly and helpful. You can spend a full day at any of the parks.

Five women talk about their experiences setting up a business in the countryside. Each woman has a different story and a different way of running her business.
A. Christine Hogan runs a computer-aided design business. She has a lot of customers and she can work from home.
B. Maggy Sasanow works from home as a designer of greetings cards. She enjoys being independent and she has a big room upstairs.
C. Delia Turner runs a curtain-making business. She has seen good times and bad times, but she is still running her business.
D. Tessa Strickland runs a children's book publishing business. She enjoys being able to work when she wants to and she has a lot of international deals.
E. Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business. She started small and has grown her business to a large size.

The Watkins family is a group of musicians. They live in South Wales, UK. The sons, Paul and Huw, are composers and prize-winning musicians. Their dad, John, makes the instruments.
One day, John needed to get his son a cello. He decided to make one himself. He took evening classes at the Welsh School of Instrument Making. After a few tries, he made a cello that was perfect for Paul.
Paul started playing the cello when he was young. He won a competition and was appointed principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra. He is now playing a new cello that was loaned to him from the Royal Academy of Music.
Huw is also a musician. He plays the piano and is a composer. He is beginning to make his own mark as a musician.
The Watkins family is proud of their sons' musical achievements. They are supportive and relaxed. They are always there to cheer their sons on.

The National Trust is an organisation that conserves the British countryside. Gareth Roberts is a warden employed by the Trust to look after the beautiful areas it owns. To be a National Trust Warden, you need to have common sense and be good at handling people. Gareth was born and bred on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he married. He has come to understand more about nature conservation since he has been with the Trust. Conservation is one of the main aspects of Gareth's work. His role is to make sure jobs get finished, with as little fuss and as economically as possible.

The Netball Captain
Suzie Ellis went to meet England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is captain of England's netball team. She had a typical day for the weeks leading up to the World Championships. She taught at a local school and had a training session in the local supermarket car park.
Kendra is very focused when she is playing. She doesn't see anything else except her movements and her feet. She might notice cars slow down out of the corner of her eye, but that's all.
The World Championships are big and important for Kendra. She wants to make sure she is at her absolute best for them. She is on a strict timetable to gain maximum fitness.
The first game is against Barbados. Kendra says they will be exciting to play. They have lots of ability.
The England team are currently ranked fourth in the world. But, as Kendra points out, the World Championships will be tough. There's no rest between games and you can still win an international series if you lose the first game. But the Championships are different because there's only one chance and you have to be ready to make the most of it.

A child who shows outstanding musical ability may need a special understanding and education. There are five music schools in Britain that provide a sympathetic environment for gifted children aged between seven and eighteen. These schools offer a range of musical activities, including individual lessons, orchestras, chamber groups, voice training, conducting and theory. They also provide a restricted academic programme, which concentrates on the essential subjects.
The disadvantages of attending a specialist music school include the cost and the need to board away from home. It may also be better to wait until the child is old enough to be able to make his or her own decisions before considering a specialist education.
For those who are equally gifted academically, there are other options. You can combine a normal school routine with musical training at one of the junior departments at the music colleges. These colleges offer Saturday morning opportunities for individual lessons with fine teachers, plus orchestral and chamber music experience.

Artist Susan Shepherd is known for her flower paintings. She has a large garden that is full of her favourite flowers, mostly tulips and poppies. Some of the plants are unruly and seed themselves all over the garden. There is a harmony of colour, shape and structure in the flower borders that line the paved path. Much of this is due to the previous owners who were keen gardeners. Susan prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants rather than on the garden as a whole. More usually, she picks them and then takes them up to her studio. Her busiest time of year is spring and early summer, when the tulips and poppies are out. She has a come-what-may attitude to the garden, rather like an affectionate aunt who is quite happy for children to run about undisciplined.
The text has been simplified by removing unnecessary details and repetitions, and the language has been made more concise and clear. The overall structure of the text has been preserved, and the answerability of the questions associated with it has not been affected.

Keeping the holiday-makers happy is a chalet girl's work. Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, is a chalet girl. She works for a company in Val d'lsere, France, cooking and cleaning for visitors who come to ski and stay in the wooden houses, known as chalets.
Sarah's day begins early. She gets up at 7 a.m. and prepares breakfast for the guests. After breakfast, she clears up and prepares the afternoon tea. She then goes on the slopes and skis as much as possible. Dinner is served at 8 p.m. and coffee is usually on the table by 10 p.m. After dinner, Sarah clears away the dinner things and fills the dishwasher. Sometimes she will stay and chat with the guests, other times they are content to be left alone.
On Sundays, Sarah has a busy day. Work begins earlier than usual and she has to clean the place and prepare breakfast for the guests. After the guests have gone, she starts cleaning madly and does the week's shop. She then prepares tea for the new guests and takes any guests needing boots or skis down to the ski shop. It is soon time for dinner duty again and perhaps a chat with friends.

Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent the day at the office of a magazine. She went to a photo studio, press previews, and a fashion shoot. She enjoyed her job at the zoo more than her job at the magazine.
Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant, spent the day at London Zoo. She stroked an elephant and thought about her future career.
Karen Hodson, a nurse, went on location with a television gardening programme. She was excited to be in the fresh air and felt strong despite her hard work.
Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. He made beds and handed out tablets. He felt satisfied despite his job being a waste of time.
Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent the day with the airline Ryanair as a member of the cabin crew. She felt self-conscious and wished she was back in the gym.
Sonia McDermott, an air hostess, spent the day as a personal trainer in a gym. She was surprised by the amount of attention given to one person and felt satisfied with her job.

On the rails, five celebrities tell Andrew Morgan their favourite memories of railway journeys. Andrea Thompson, a newsreader, fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and tries to get back there as often as she can. There's a local train from Cannes along the coast which crosses the border with Italy. It takes you past some of the most amazing seascapes. The journey is always enchanting, regardless of the weather or time of the year. You feel like someone peeping into the property of the rich and famous. The travellers themselves are always lively because there is an interesting mix of tourists and locals, all with different itineraries but all admirers of the breathtaking journey.
Raj Patel, an explorer, has enjoyed many rail journeys through the years, but if he had to pick a favourite, it would be the Nile Valley Express, which runs across the desert of northern Sudan. The journey was marred by one misfortune in his youth, missing out on a family train journey from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park. Martin Brown, a journalist, was working on a series of articles based on a round-the-world trip and had to cross a dessert in an African country. There wasn't a road, so the only way to continue their journey was to take the Desert Express. Arisu Mezuki, an actress, was brought up in Singapore and Cyprus, where she saw very few trains, let alone travelled on them. It wasn't until she was a teenager that trains began to dominate her life.

Trying to get published? If you are thinking about writing and want to know where to send your story, Margaret Stubbs has some advice for you. To be successful, you need to research your markets, find out about publishers, and practice your writing skills. You also need to develop a knowledge of the markets you are aiming at. To do this, you can read everything relevant you can lay your hands on. Use your local library and go round the local bookshops and newsagents. Reading widely will always give you the best guide to what kinds of writing publishers are actually accepting at any given time. If you have only written one story or one article, it is not at all likely to be published. So, keep writing and don't be discouraged.

No Title
I was waiting at the Baltimore railway station for the 10.10 to Philadelphia. There were a lot of people waiting. The station was not clean and polished like it usually is. There were elderly couples with matching luggage and swarms of college kids. A man was walking around talking to different strangers. He was well-off. He went up to a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. He came over to me and asked me if I was travelling to Philadelphia. I said yes, but he didn't ask me to go with him. He was probably worried about his daughter. He was talking about his daughter and her passport. He said he had to stay with his wife because she was in a wheelchair. I let my eyes wander toward the two of them. The man was holding a packet. It looked to be stapled shut. I said silently, "Watch yourself, lady."

John Moore, a restaurant owner, writes about his relationship with his son Gary, a famous TV chef. Gary was given his chance to shine in the kitchen, and his dad ran a restaurant. When John heard about an opportunity, he rushed to look at the place. It was perfect for his business. John and his wife dedicated themselves to running the restaurant and raising their children. They lived over the restaurant and always put a lot of emphasis on having meals together.
Gary was a lively child who loved to cook. He started helping his dad in the kitchen at a young age. By the age of 15, he was as good as any of the men working there. He went to catering college and started his own business. Gary is successful and has a lot of talent. He's helped other people out and is proud of his accomplishments.
John is proud of his son and believes that if you want something, you have to work hard for it. He also thinks that if you talk to your children as they grow up, and if they only take in ten per cent of what you've told them, you should be happy.

Finding a good flat in Dublin was like finding gold in the gold rush. If you knew someone who knew someone who was leaving a place, that often worked. But if you had just arrived in Dublin, there was no chance of any personal contact. You had to stay in a hostel and search.
Jo felt like she was stepping into the unknown when she got on the train to go and work there. She didn't ask herself why she was going there in the first place. She was heading off on her own.
There was an advertisement for a flat in Ringsend that said, 'Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom.' It was very near the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true.
She went to the flat and met a cheerful-looking girl with a college scarf. The girl was coming down the stairs and said, "Is this all there is to it? Oh dear, oh dear," in a posh accent.
They offered her a mug of tea and she stayed for a while.

Dolphins are popular animals that people love to see. They are intelligent, sensitive to human emotions, and allow us to dream of freedom. However, dolphins are facing a number of threats, including pollution, overfishing, and human disturbance.
The main cause of death for dolphins is being caught in fishermen's nets. This is because porpoises have to find their food within a limited time. If fish in one area are removed by fishing, they may not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. Dolphins are also in danger of getting caught in fishermen's nets which are thought to be invisible to them.
Another threat to dolphins is pollution. Waste and other substances found in the sea can be stored in the bodies of dolphins. One example is what happens with pesticides: these poisons are soluble in fat, which means that the dolphins can digest them and they can build up in their bodies.
Finally, dolphins are also threatened by human disturbance. Noise pollution from ships, oil wells and other sources can disturb the dolphins in ways that we do not yet understand.

Getting fit is essential for your mind, body and spirit. It's a great way to maintain a perfect balance when everything seems more and more unbalanced. There are plenty of reasons why you should exercise and very few - for most of us why you shouldn't. Exercise improves muscle tone and provides quick changes in body shape. It helps prevent muscle imbalances which can lead to injuries. It also improves the condition of your heart and lungs and blood circulation. If you're not sure, you should consult your doctor on what's good for you personally. Stretching is a great way to improve flexibility and ease of movement, and helps you to maintain correct posture and to prevent muscle tears and injuries caused by overuse. If done four or five times a week, it will guarantee a more flexible,fitter body. So stretching should play an important part in your exercise routine, which should be performed both slowly and precisely.

In their natural habitat, film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman are often away from their home comforts for months on end. They are searching for the perfect shot. Two of the hardest creatures to track down in East Africa are Amanda and Owen. Their present habitat, the Ngorongoro Crater, has been affected by a lot of rain. They had to invest in an expensive piece of equipment to help them when their vehicles get stuck in the mud. Their partnership has created some of TV's finest wildlife films. They are currently trailing a shy animal, the jackal. Film-makers have been travelling the world to point cameras at exotic wildlife since the birth of television. The appeal of being alone in such remote areas is that we can get close enough to the animals to become part of their lives.

The Netball Captain
Suzie Ellis went to meet England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is captain of England's netball team. She had a typical day for the weeks leading up to the World Championships. She taught at a local school and had a training session in the local supermarket car park.
Kendra is very focused on her training. She said, "My whole life now is all about making sure I'm at my absolute best for the Championships." She is on a strict timetable to gain maximum fitness for the Championships.
The World Championships will be tough. There will be a lot of pressure on the England team. But Kendra is confident that they can win. She said, "You don't do all that training not to come out a winner."
Netball is also taking a far more scientific approach to fitness testing. Kendra said, "It is essential that we all think and train like world-class players."
As captain, Kendra has a strong mental attitude and leads by example. She said, "From the very beginning, my netball career has always been carefully planned." So she took the decision some time ago that this competition would be the end of it as far as playing is concerned.

In hot water, Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time studying the chemical processes happening in the sea. She teaches and does research into marine geochemistry. She is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she isn't teaching, she dives down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.
A dive can last for 16 hours. If there is a problem, you can hit a panic button and the escape vessel will be released. No-one has tested it yet, but it would be a very unpleasant journey.
When Rachel isn't at sea, she is in her office at the Oceanography Centre. Two thirds of her salary comes from teaching, which she loves.
The only time Rachel has been frightened is when she first went down with the Americans. There was an explosion and she thought, "I'm going to die." But she was still alive.
It's such an adventure diving down to the deepest part of the ocean. Every time Rachel looks out of the porthole and sees the underwater volcanoes, there is such a sense of wonder.

First impressions are often lasting ones. People form impressions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They observe our appearance, our eye contact, our body language and how fast or slowly we talk, our volume and tone of voice as well as our actual words.
Mary Pearce was a teacher who worked hard to earn her degree and was confident when she graduated. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. However, she didn't get the job because the Head Teacher thought she didn't fit the image of an office manager.
Movement and gestures also influence an interviewer's first impression of a candidate. When our facial expressions and our words send different messages the listener will put more weight on the non-verbal message. So make sure your words agree with your body language.
Finally, a consideration of what we say and how we say it will contribute to the success of an interview. If you are able to communicate clearly and concisely, you are more likely to make a good impression.

Matt Froggatt was an insurance agent in London. He decided to leave his job and start a sheep farm. He was made redundant and had enough money to set up the farm. He also supplies meat through mail order.
Ron Able was a manager in advertising. He decided to become an artist. He talked to a career counsellor and went to the north of England to start his new business.
Katherine Goodison was a lawyer. She decided to set up her own business making hats. She feels happier and less stressed now.
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance. He decided to become a masseur. He spent a year travelling and getting qualifications. He has no regrets.

Four young sports stars talk about their lives. Each one has a different sport they excel at.
Darius is a runner. He has been sporty since he was young. He played a lot of different sports, but he was best at football and athletics. He competed for his country in the youth team and won a medal.
Gabriel is a surfer. He loves surfing and is very dedicated to his sport. He has to give up late-night parties and early mornings to train. He won the National Championships last year and got picked to present a surfing series on TV.
Dieter is a yacht racer. He loves sailing and is very traditional. He celebrates wins in great style, but he doesn't actively go looking for media coverage.
Tomas is a tennis player. He loves playing tennis and is very serious about his sport. He has to travel a lot and make sacrifices for his sport.

Young shoppers often go to the supermarket with their parents. Sometimes, parents feel frustrated and guilty when they have to say no to their children's demands. It can be difficult to decide which demands should be agreed to and which should be refused. Parents also admit they are inconsistent and hypocritical in their responses to their children's purchasing requests. Supermarkets could do a lot more to ease parent-child conflict.

The Merrion Hotel is a five-star hotel that has recently opened in Dublin. It is a new hotel that has been created using four large eighteenth-century houses. The hotel has a lot of technology, including a computer system that can deal with return clients and a system that controls room temperature. The hotel also has a lot of amenities, such as a swimming pool, gym, conference rooms, bars, and restaurants.
The Merrion Hotel is likely to be successful because of its technology, its amenities, and its highly capable staff.

Where I get my energy, Emma Marsden asked six women who live life to the full to tell us how they do it. They said that doing things you enjoy and feeling positive about life gives you energy. If you enjoy something, it doesn't make you feel low even though you may be feeling tired. To get energy, you can do things that make you feel good, such as dancing, exercising, or spending time in nature. You also need to get enough sleep and eat a healthy diet.

Ice skating has a long history. People have been skating for thousands of years. In the past, people used skates made from animal bone. Now, people use skates made from metal. Skating is a popular sport that can be enjoyed by people of all ages. To skate, you need to be relaxed and have good balance. You also need to know how to fall safely. Once you have learned the basics, you can practice different styles of skating. Skating is a great way to improve your balance, coordination, and overall health.

There are many young people in the world who are passionate about their hobbies. Some of these hobbies include gymnastics, show-jumping, chess, and music.
A young girl named Julia Gregson won a gold medal for gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She is ambitious and wants to become a physiotherapist and compete at the next Olympics.
Another young girl named Sarah Stokes made her first show-jumping appearance at ten. She is also ambitious and wants to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team and win a gold medal at the Olympics.
A young girl named Jane McShane is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. She is also ambitious and wants to win a gold medal at the Olympics.
These young people are all passionate about their hobbies and are working hard to achieve their goals. They are an inspiration to everyone.

Chris Greener was tall when he was fourteen, and he is still the tallest man in Britain today. Every decade, the average height of people in Europe grows another centimetre. More and more people are being born who are very tall. This does not mean that humanity is producing a new super race. We are returning to what we were like as cavemen. Our ancestors used to eat a wide variety of foods, but today we mostly eat three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice and maize. This poor diet has had a disastrous effect on human health and physique. From then on, agriculture spread because it could support more people. However, the fact that most people relying on this system are poorly nourished and stunted has only recently been tackled. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm.

Studio audiences are a common feature of television life. They are made up of people from all classes, professions and income groups. People often go to studio audiences to appear on television, take a look behind the scenes, or simply have fun.
When you sit in a studio audience, you are squashed among strangers and someone flashes cards with APPLAUD or LAUGH on them. You clap or laugh accordingly. This may reflect the reality of some television, but not all by any means.
Going to a studio may be a terrible way to watch television, but that's not what's important. For most of the audience, it was simply fun and a free night of entertainment.

Bruce, Sophia, Matthew, Annette, and James all have their favourite places in England. They like different landscapes, but they all appreciate the human element and the beauty of nature.
Bruce likes landscapes with old temples and villages. Sophia enjoys a miniature railway journey through back gardens. Matthew loves the remote and lovely coast. Annette prefers wide-open moorland for hiking. James purchased his favourite house, Glenthorne, where he can find peace and reconnect with his English roots.
Each person has their own unique way of experiencing their favourite place. Bruce finds beauty in the old temples and villages. Sophia finds joy in exploring the countryside and seeing people's daily lives. Matthew finds peace and tranquility in the natural beauty of the coast. Annette finds solace in the feeling of space and freedom in the moorland. James finds happiness in the tranquility and romance of his beloved house.
They all appreciate the beauty and diversity of England's landscapes and the importance of preserving them for future generations.

We love animals. One day, my daughter found a pine snake. We decided to keep it overnight. I was late getting home and when I arrived, there was a crisis. In our fast-paced world, letter writing is at risk of disappearing. However, I believe there is something special about receiving a letter that cannot be matched by any other form of communication. It's the excitement of its arrival, the pleasure of seeing who it is from, and the enjoyment of the contents. Letter writing has been part of my life for as long as I can remember. It probably began with the little notes I would write to my mother. My mother also always insisted I write my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday presents. When I left home to train as a doctor in London, I would write once a week, and so would my mother. I have a penfriend in Australia and another in Vancouver. I also write to my family and friends in Sri Lanka and France. I am pleased that my children are carrying on the tradition. Like my mother before me, I insist they write their own thank-you letters.

Tens of thousands of ancient pictures carved into the rocks at Mont Bego in the French Alps are being damaged. The drawings include pictures of cows with horns, cultivated fields and various gods and goddesses. But as the popularity of the site increases, the pictures are being ruined by thoughtless graffiti.
The drawings are being damaged rapidly and will not survive for future generations. People are stamping on the drawings, wearing away the rock and definition of the artwork as they do so. Some visitors even chop off parts to take home as souvenirs.
Experts are divided over the best way to preserve the drawings. Some believe that the only way to save the site is to turn the whole mountain into a 'no-go' area. Others want to allow people to look at the site but impose rules to prevent damage.
The main problem is financial. There is not enough money to hire enough guards to prevent visitors from damaging the drawings. There may also have to be a charge for visitors.
The damage to the drawings is increasing rapidly and there is a need to take action to preserve them for future generations.

Going up the wall was once a challenge. Now it can be done anywhere, indoors or out. The crowd holds its breath. High above them on the climbing wall, hanging upside down by the tips of two fingers, is the French climber Francois Lombard. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at Birmingham's National Indoor Arena. The National Indoor Arena is famous for staging the TV show Gladiators, but it also hosts the World Cup Climbing Championships. The fact that either event is possible is the result of a new and rapidly developing technology. Until the mid-1960s, climbers practised their skills on cliffs. During the winter they would either tolerate the cold weather or go walking instead. As the sport developed, it was increasingly important for top climbers to keep fit. With the cliffs unusable for much of the year, they used brick-edges or stone buildings to 'work out' on. Many sports centres started building walls specifically for climbing. These walls followed the example set by Don Robinson, a teacher of physical education, who constructed a climbing wall in a corridor of his department at Leeds University.

Chris Greener was tall when he was fourteen, and he is still the tallest man in Britain today. Every decade, the average height of people in Europe grows another centimetre. More and more people are being born who are very tall. This does not mean that humanity is producing a new super race. We are returning to what we were like as cavemen. Our ancestors used to eat a wide variety of foods, but today we mostly eat three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice and maize. This poor diet has had a disastrous effect on human health and physique. From then on, agriculture spread because it could support more people. However, the fact that most people relying on this system are poorly nourished and stunted has only recently been tackled. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm.

Two brothers, Dave and Norm Lagasse, are playing a game called pichenotte. It is a game that their grandfather brought to the USA from Canada. The game is popular in their family and they often play it on weekends and holidays.
Pichenotte is a game of skill. Each competitor gets 12 pieces or 'pucks'. These are flicked across a wheel-like board using the middle or index finger of one hand. Flicking a puck into a small hole is worth 20 points. The game usually lasts just two minutes.
The Lagasses have made a business out of their love for the game. They sell boards and they also hold championships. They have made more than 450 boards and they are available for $595 each.
The Lagasses are happy to spend their off-duty hours playing the game they hope will make their fortune.

Week after week, British tabloid newspapers publish pictures that intrude into people's privacy. Although pop stars sometimes pose for paparazzi, this is not typical. More usually, great damage is done to individuals in the public eye when their private moments are captured on the front page. Very few people call on the services of the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), an organisation that was set up to deal with issues of this kind. The pictures in the public interest are rarely in the public interest. Do intimate shots of pop stars help to detect a crime? In what way did the picture of a famous actress on a hotel bedroom balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has made a fuss about long-lens pictures in the past and since she was in a hotel, a place where there is a reasonable expectation of privacy, she had good cause for complaint, but she didn't take any action. The PCC should take the initiative on this and other shameful attacks. To begin with, this seems like a great idea. It would surely lead to many decisions against newspapers. Even photographers would be affected, no longer finding it financially possible to spend their days hidden behind trees waiting to snap unsuspecting celebrities. However, there are also some concerns about taking on this role. How would the PCC decide whether or not to launch an inquiry? And if the person involved still refuses to do anything, should the PCC proceed nevertheless?

Paul Forster goes to a kite-flying festival in Malaysia. He spends a nervous night in the forest. He met a man named Adnan Ali who showed him how to make kites. They sat down in the shade of the trees and looked out over the festival. The festival had a lot of kites and platforms. The kites flew into the air like rockets. There were a lot of people registered for the competition. Each person had entered four different designs. The competition ran for five days. Paul decided to stay in the forest for a night. He drank cold tea and ate fish crackers. He explored the southern half of the state and pointed his car inland on the road to Kuala Lumpur. He took a wrong turn and ended up at a river. He took a boat across the river and walked up a steep path. He found a place to stay and spent the night. The next day he woke up and saw a beautiful view of the mountains. It rained and he got wet. He slid downhill and wondered how the giant butterflies avoided the drops. He was glad that his car was still there. He went back to Kota Bahru and talked to the people. He remembered Kelantan more for its human kindness than its kites.

What kind of shopper are you? We all go shopping, but there are different types of shoppers. Do you know which kind you are? Abby Edwards asked around and found out that there are different types of shoppers. Some people are addicted to shopping, while others are reluctant or even hate it.
There are different reasons why people shop differently. Some people, like Melanie and her boyfriend, enjoy shopping and spend a lot of money. Others, like Brenda, don't enjoy shopping and tend to feel guilty when they spend money. Still others, like Juliet, only shop for essentials. And there are those who, like Lisa, enjoy shopping but don't buy very much.
So, what kind of shopper are you? Take a look at the different types of shoppers and see which one you most identify with.
